instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> screen goes blank and shuts off intermittently
threads.message:
So we got a mpb 17 with this board.
At first the machine would not even start. By watching multiple videos where Luis addresses this issue I was speculating immediately that the "classic" <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> cap issue will be the problem. 
Measured voltage on it, it was 0.3V. Changed the cap to a non tantulum one.
The machine would start up. It seemed that we fixed it but when the owner came back and installed own ssd and optibay the machine would turn itself off just after boot.
When we try to boot from external hdd it works. Also tried connecting multiple usb devices that suck power but it would work fine. But when we boot with the hard drive installed in still shuts down every now and then.

Another issue that might be connected is that the screen will turn itself off quite oftenly. Tried felxing the motherboard just in the area above the fan where the vRams are and the screen would go on and off.
Measured all rails, everything seems normal.
No idea where to look next.
Thanks for the help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> screen goes blank and shuts off intermittently
threads.message: <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> is a common problem. You can try to reflow it, but that does not always work. Pulling it and rebelling it is the best solution. I would advice to practice on a scrap board first!
